review.title: Modelling Creativity: Identifying Key Components through a Corpus-Based Approach
review.abstract: Creativity is a complex, multi-faceted concept encompassing a variety of related aspects, abilities, properties and behaviours. If we wish to study creativity scientifically, then a tractable and well-articulated model of creativity is required. Such a model would be of great value to researchers investigating the nature of creativity and in particular, those concerned with the evaluation of creative practice. This paper describes a unique approach to developing a suitable model of how creative behaviour emerges that is based on the words people use to describe the concept. Using techniques from the field of statistical natural language processing, we identify a collection of fourteen key components of creativity through an analysis of a corpus of academic papers on the topic. Words are identified which appear significantly often in connection with discussions of the concept. Using a measure of lexical similarity to help cluster these words, a number of distinct themes emerge, which collectively contribute to a comprehensive and multi-perspective model of creativity. The components provide an ontology of creativity: a set of building blocks which can be used to model creative practice in a variety of domains. The components have been employed in two case studies to evaluate the creativity of computational systems and have proven useful in articulating achievements of this work and directions for further research.

If we want to scientifically examine creativity, we need a comprehensible and well-articulated model of creativity, which would be of great value to researchers investigating the nature of creativity, especially those engaged in evaluating creative practice. This paper describes a unique approach to developing a suitable model of how creative behavior emerges based on the words people use to describe the concept. Using techniques from the field of statistical processing of natural language, we identify a collection of fourteen key components of creativity through an analysis of a corpus of scientific papers on the subject, identifying words that occur significantly frequently in the context of discussions of the concept.

sections.heading: Components of creativity
sections.text: From the analytical steps described in the previous section, it was possible to filter out a number of fourteen key components of creativity, which are summarized in Fig. 7 and are presented in more detail below. Collectively, these components contribute to the overall concept and can be regarded as providing an ontology of creativity. However, it is important to note that the fourteen components do not constitute a set of necessary and sufficient conditions for creativity in all its possible manifestations, for two reasons. Firstly, some of the components that we have identified appear to be logically incompatible with others in the set. Consider, for example, the obvious need for autonomous, independent behavior that is identified in independence and freedom, and contrast this with the requirement for social interaction implied by social interaction and communication. Secondly, creativity manifests itself in quite different ways in different areas [12] and components that vary in importance.

sections.text: Independent working with autonomy over actions and decisions. Freedom to work without being tied to existing solutions, processes or biases; perhaps a challenge to cultural or domain-specific norms.

sections.text: Personal and emotional investment, immersion, self-expression and participation in the creative process. Intention and desire to be creative: Creativity is its own reward, a positive process that gives fulfillment and joy.

sections.heading: Originality:
sections.text: Novelty and originality; a new product, or doing something in a new way; recognizing new connections and relationships between previously unrelated concepts. Results that are unpredictable, unexpected, surprising, unusual and exceptional.

metadata.abstractText: Creativity is a complex, multi-faceted concept encompassing a variety of related aspects, abilities, properties and behaviours. If we wish to study creativity scientifically, then a tractable and well-articulated model of creativity is required. Such a model would be of great value to researchers investigating the nature of creativity and in particular, those concerned with the evaluation of creative practice. This paper describes a unique approach to developing a suitable model of how creative behaviour emerges that is based on the words people use to describe the concept. Using techniques from the field of statistical natural language processing, we identify a collection of fourteen key components of creativity through an analysis of a corpus of academic papers on the topic. Words are identified which appear significantly often in connection with discussions of the concept. Using a measure of lexical similarity to help cluster these words, a number of distinct themes emerge, which collectively contribute to a comprehensive and multi-perspective model of creativity. The components provide an ontology of creativity: a set of building blocks which can be used to model creative practice in a variety of domains. The components have been employed in two case studies to evaluate the creativity of computational systems and have proven useful in articulating achievements of this work and directions for further research.
